name: Greek Pantheon
description: The Greek pantheon encompasses the gods and goddesses of ancient Greek mythology, centered on Mount Olympus and featuring the twelve Olympians who ruled after the Titanomachy.
detailedHistory:
## Origins of the Olympians

The Greek pantheon emerged from the mingling of indigenous Pelasgian beliefs with the sky-god traditions of invading Hellenic tribes.

### The Golden Age

Before the gods, there were the Titans, ruled by Cronus. This was a time of peace and prosperity, but also stagnation. The rise of Zeus and the Olympians marked the beginning of a new cosmic order—civilization, law, and justice replacing the raw elemental forces of the Titans.

### Mount Olympus

The twelve major gods (Olympians) dwelt on Mount Olympus, the highest peak in Greece. From their divine palaces, they observed human affairs, intervening to reward piety or punish hubris.

name: Norse Pantheon
description: The Norse pantheon includes the Aesir and Vanir gods of Scandinavian mythology, centered in Asgard and featuring stories of creation, heroism, and the prophesied end of the world known as Ragnarok.
detailedHistory:
## The World Tree and Ragnarok

Norse mythology centers on Yggdrasil, the Ash Tree connecting the nine worlds. The Aesir (sky gods) and Vanir (earth gods) eventually unified after a war.

### The Prophecy

Unique among mythologies, the Norse gods know their end. **Ragnarok** is the prophesied twilight of the gods, where they will battle the frost giants and chaos monsters, resulting in the destruction and renewal of the world.

name: Egyptian Pantheon
description: The Egyptian pantheon encompasses the gods and goddesses of ancient Egypt, featuring creation deities, solar worship, the afterlife, and the eternal struggle between order (Ma'at) and chaos (Isfet).
detailedHistory:
## Gods of the Nile

Egyptian mythology is one of the longest-enduring religious systems in history. It focused heavily on the afterlife, the sun's journey, and the maintenance of *Ma'at* (cosmic order).

### The Afterlife

The Egyptians believed the soul faced judgment in the Hall of Truth, where the heart was weighed against the feather of Ma'at. Only the righteous could enter the Field of Reeds.

name: Roman Pantheon
description: The Roman pantheon adapted and expanded upon Greek mythology, creating a rich religious tradition that emphasized duty, piety, and the divine favor of the state. The Romans identified their gods with Greek counterparts while maintaining distinct characteristics and rituals.

name: Hindu Pantheon
description: Hindu mythology encompasses thousands of years of religious and philosophical tradition from the Indian subcontinent. Centered on the Trimurti (Brahma the Creator, Vishnu the Preserver, and Shiva the Destroyer) and featuring countless gods, goddesses, and avatars.

name: Japanese Pantheon
description: Shinto (Way of the Kami) is the indigenous spirituality of Japan, featuring countless kami (divine spirits or gods) associated with natural phenomena, ancestors, and sacred places.

name: Celtic Pantheon
description: The deities of the Celtic peoples, associated with nature, magic, war, and sovereignty. Known for the Tuatha Dé Danann in Irish mythology.

name: Aztec Pantheon
description: A complex pantheon centered on duality, sacrifice, and the sun, demanding blood sacrifice to sustain the cosmos.

name: Chinese Pantheon
description: A vast bureaucracy of gods, spirits, and immortals reflecting the imperial government on earth, blending Taoism, Buddhism, and folk religion.
